byline.contributor: Michael S. Schmidt reported from Chicago, and Matt Apuzzo from Washington.
byline.original: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and MATT APUZZO

abstract: Federal Bureau of Investigation Dir James B Comey says that additional scrutiny and criticism of police officers after highly publicized incidents of police brutality has led to increase in violent crime in some cities as officers have become less aggressive; his remarks catch Justice Dept officials, who do not share same view, by surprise; Comey acknowledges no data yet backs up his opinion.
lead_paragraph: James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director, said he had a “strong sense” that scrutiny of the police has made officers less aggressive and emboldened criminals.

headline.main: F.B.I. Chief Links Scrutiny of Police With Rise in Violent Crime
headline.print_headline: F.B.I. Chief Links Eyes on Police to Rise in Crime

snippet: James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director, said he had a “strong sense” that scrutiny of the police has made officers less aggressive and emboldened criminals.
